posts.name: Abi
posts.cooked:
Does anyone have experience with/thoughts on using 3D printer slider blocks (instead of radial bearings) to keep telescoping arm stages aligned?

We are building a chain-driven telescoping arm (inspired by the iconic Pink Arm) and will be putting these slider blocks attached to the first (2.5x2.5") and second (1x1") stage aluminum tubes.

We were originally going to print them out of Nylon, but due to time constraints and moisture issues, we will not be able to do so. We’re hoping to print from PLA instead and sand the outer edges to make the surface that will be in contact with the outer aluminum tubes more smooth.

Photos for reference: Screenshot_20230202-102627 1440×3040 224 KB Screenshot_20230202-102608 1440×3040 204 KB

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked:
We prototyped some 3D-Printed sliders last year while we waited for our Thrifty Telescoping Tube Kits to arrive. Even just going vertical, they were not very good. They bound up, had a lot of friction, and the blocks became damaged sometimes. Since you are doing a pink arm which would go horizontal, I would suggest either not doing a block (probably not what you want, but our rack and pinion arm w/o a block works very well), or printing a block with spots to put bearings in. thethriftybot.com has a lot of different bearing offerings. We actually designed something similar to what you seem to be looking for with spaces for bearings. Let me know and I can post a picture later, but the gist of it is you have a hole in both sides of the block where you can run a 1/4-20 bolt through and put bearings into gaps in the block.

Edit: See above, we basically did that

posts.name: Abi
posts.cooked:
Woah those are awesome! Will save us so much time too…

Did you have bearings at the top as well, or just plugged into the bottom of the tubes of each stage?

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Right now just on the bottom, we are just getting the arm together so we may make a few more geometry changes, but this form looks like it will work well.   Our current prototype is printed out of regular PLA but we will move to Duramic PLA before the season and if that isn’t enough we may have Thrifty print some out of Onyx (Nylon Carbon Fiber)

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked: You definitely want bearings. Less likely to wrack and jam, lower friction so less likely to bind, and if you have a 3D printer, easy to make and adapt (or steal from Bmongar’s OnShape).

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
As big of a fan I am about using bushing/slider surfaces bearings are probably a good call. Or at the very least a compromise where you have nylon bushings on a ground axle (dowel pin) that sits in a 3d printed housing (just like the bearing examples, but with bushings instead). Tighter packaging and very economical vs a stack of bearings. Also allows the use of thinner walled tube as it may be easier to spread the loads out over a greater surface in 1/16 wall tubing (or thinner).

If it falls out of your hand when you try to drop it it is too heavy.

Edit: you will probably want this implementation as a pre-quals and pre-elims checklist item to monitor wear until you know how things react, at the end of the day these are plastic bearing surfaces (although you could upgrade to bronze or other materials), the caveat being with small diameter stuff you have greater contact loads, so you want more of them to help spread the load vs a large bearing solution.

posts.name: Pranav Gupta
posts.cooked: I copied the WCP endblocks and printed them out with PETG and used bearings. They work great and I doubt they’re gonna fail since the 3d printed part is not touching the metal.

posts.name: Robert Woodhead
posts.cooked:
I played with a 3D printed lifting arm as a personal project last year. I found that simple sliding bearings printed in PLA worked quite well, and using some spray silicone made them work even better. Of course, much will depend on how heavy the arm is and consequently the load on the bearing surfaces.

See this posting for details and links to the files, they may be of some use to you: The CheapLifter - a 3D-printed Lift System

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked: Where a lot of people are seeing some difficulties is translating arms designed to lift vertically or near-vertically being used to extend horizontallyish with side-load on the end effector.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked:
I have found printed bushings to be excellent for individual telescoping stages that are fully driven (not spring extended).  With the low extension force a spring provides I would worry about friction, and the racking forces on linked parallel stages could also be an issue, but as long as you keep decent overlap and size parts correctly binding should be fine.  We have used printed bushings for the 2020 & 2022 climbers, and are using them for the linear stage of a pink arm this year (1x1.5 tube inside of 2x2 tube).

Our design practice has been to ensure 6"+ of overlap, but we also print them from nylon.  Overture brand “easy nylon” is a good choice for most printers.  One year we even undersized the nylon bushing and soaked it overnight in PTFE lubricant, allowing the part to swell and become effectively oil impregnated for reduced friction.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: One more key I should mention is that you want to avoid long contact surfaces between the sliding tube and the plastic.  So for a 6" bushing overlap I would only have maybe 1.5" of contact at each end of the 6" block, not full contact for 6".  You also want to avoid contact with the full tube cross section and instead only engage the corners.  That reduces friction and helps prevent the imperfect flatness of extruded aluminum tubes from binding at certain points in the travel.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: You will want some m5 10 heat set inserts so you have something to screw into.  We used m5 10 7 but  5"10 5 would work too. We have this set https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B08Z86Z85R?psc=1&ref=ppx_pop_mob_b_asin_title

posts.name: Robert Woodhead
posts.cooked: It is somewhat of a “your mileage may vary” situation. Whether or not sliding bearing blocks will work will depend on the mass of the end-effector, the power of the constant-force springs (if passively extending), the angle of the arm when extending, and in particular, how much overlap there is between the tubes at max extension – the more overlap, the less the extended arm is levering the bearing contact surfaces. A 30" inner tube that only extends 15" is going to slide a lot easier than a 30" inner tube that extends 25".

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked: Yup.

posts.name: Don Biery
posts.cooked: Your Design is awesome. You could mitigate some of the wear issues with either some UHMW railes you epoxy on or VHB tape on (clamp over night).  Another way would be get the glide filament from IGUS and print them out of that material.  Also proper lubrication is always helpful, We use similar blocks last year on our climber arm, same block the whole season, through worlds, used White Lithium, which works well with the UHMW, but research depending on what material you print it with.

posts.name: Abi
posts.cooked:
Thank you everyone for all your help! So many great solutions to this challenge.

Though I love the idea of the tube end plugs with bearings/rollers/bushings, that unfortunately will not work for our design since the tubes have already been cut and the design relies on the arm to retract as much as possible. I popped them into CAD, but just couldn’t get them to fit.

Instead, we’re going with a hollow top tube cap that will have holders for bushings (we’re gonna try PLA ones first rotating around screws) and then a small support block fixed to the bottom of each stage made out of Teflon or UHMW (whichever we can get our hands on faster). With careful packaging, the plugs nest inside each other so that the top (and bottom) of stage 1 and the outer housing are flush when retracted.

The 3D printed plugs also have cutouts on the non-roller sides for our sprockets and chains that drive the arm extension to pass through. The rollers will be on the top and bottom of the arm to prevent binding (extension at a 35 degree angle), and the chains will be on the side. The Teflon/UHMW blocks will hopefully help prevent any sideways binding and keep the stages aligned while they’re retracted into the outer housing.

CAD: Onshape

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
thesteminist:

we’re gonna try PLA ones first rotating around screws)

Absolutely fine for prototyping, you really don’t want threads in contact with the roller as it will cause wear and thrust loading potentially binding and increasing friction. McMaster sells some [shoulder screws](McMaster-Carr Page: McMaster-Carr ) with long shoulders that may be your speed. Couple this with a few nylon spacers from he hardware store and you have a great prototype.

Another question:

Are forces along the red axis on each stage just taken up by sliding surfaces like you initially proposed?

posts.name: Abi
posts.cooked:
Screws with threads only on the end the plan, similar to what is used to hold the bearings in the Thrifty Telescoping Kit.

And yes, the bottom slider blocks will be primarily responsible for constraining the red forces (which will be left to right with the way we will mount the arm), although with proper tensioning, the chain anchor will also help with this, although we’re not relying on it. We’re not opposed to a bottom-of-the-stage bushing contraption that slips onto the outside of the stages either, but we will prototype and see what works best.
